questions.stem: In Sperling's (1960) partial-report paradigm, participants could accurately report any cued row of a briefly flashed letter array when cued immediately, but this advantage disappeared after approximately 500 milliseconds. This finding provided evidence for:

options.text: The limited capacity of short-term memory (7 plus or minus 2 items)
A brief, high-capacity visual sensory memory store (iconic memory)
The phonological loop component of working memory
The superiority of semantic encoding over structural encoding

questions.explanation: Sperling's partial-report paradigm demonstrated iconic memory -- a brief (approximately 250-500 ms), high-capacity visual sensory memory store. When cued immediately, participants could report any row, indicating that all information was briefly available. But after about 500 ms, the iconic trace had faded, and participants could only report 4-5 items (the capacity of short-term memory). This dissociation between immediate full availability and rapid decay defines iconic memory as distinct from short-term memory.

questions.stem: A patient with bilateral hippocampal damage (similar to patient H.M.) is asked to learn mirror drawing over three practice sessions. Which of the following outcomes would be expected?

options.text: The patient cannot learn the task because all forms of memory are impaired
The patient shows normal improvement in mirror-drawing skill but has no conscious memory of practicing
The patient shows no improvement because procedural memory requires hippocampal consolidation
The patient can describe the practice sessions but shows no motor improvement

questions.explanation: Patient H.M. demonstrated the critical dissociation between explicit and implicit memory. Despite severe anterograde amnesia for declarative information (he could not remember having practiced), H.M. showed normal improvement on procedural tasks like mirror drawing across sessions. This occurs because procedural (implicit) memory depends on the basal ganglia, cerebellum, and motor cortex rather than the hippocampus. Each session, he would deny ever having done the task before but would perform progressively better.

questions.stem: According to Baddeley's working memory model, which component serves as the attentional control system that coordinates the other subsystems, shifts focus, and inhibits irrelevant information?

options.text: Phonological loop
Visuospatial sketchpad
Central executive
Episodic buffer

questions.explanation: The central executive is the attentional control system in Baddeley's working memory model. It coordinates the phonological loop and visuospatial sketchpad, shifts attentional focus between tasks, inhibits irrelevant responses, and allocates limited attentional resources. It is the most clinically relevant component, with deficits associated with prefrontal cortex damage and ADHD. The phonological loop maintains verbal information, the visuospatial sketchpad handles visual-spatial information, and the episodic buffer (added in 2000) integrates information across subsystems.

questions.stem: George Miller's (1956) influential paper 'The Magical Number Seven, Plus or Minus Two' established that the capacity of short-term memory is approximately:

options.text: 3-4 items, which can be expanded through rehearsal
5-9 items, which can be expanded through chunking
12-15 items, which decays rapidly without attention
Unlimited capacity with a duration of approximately 30 seconds

questions.explanation: Miller's classic paper established that short-term memory capacity is approximately 7 plus or minus 2 items (i.e., 5-9 items). This capacity limit can be effectively expanded through chunking -- grouping individual items into larger meaningful units. For example, the 10-digit sequence 1941177620 can be chunked as 1941-1776-20 (two historical dates plus a number), reducing the memory load from 10 items to 3 chunks. The duration of STM without rehearsal is approximately 15-30 seconds.

questions.stem: An amnesic patient shows normal performance on a word-stem completion task (being more likely to complete 'MOT___' as 'MOTEL' after seeing 'MOTEL' earlier) despite having no conscious recollection of seeing the word. This demonstrates intact:

options.text: Episodic memory
Semantic memory
Priming (implicit memory)
Working memory capacity

questions.explanation: Priming is a form of implicit memory in which prior exposure to a stimulus influences subsequent processing without conscious awareness. Word-stem completion is a classic priming task: having previously seen 'MOTEL' increases the likelihood of completing 'MOT___' as 'MOTEL' rather than alternatives like 'MOTOR.' Amnesic patients show intact priming despite impaired explicit (conscious) recall, demonstrating that priming relies on neocortical perceptual and association areas rather than the hippocampal system required for explicit memory. This dissociation is strong evidence for multiple memory systems.

questions.stem: Select all components of Baddeley and Hitch's (1974) working memory model, including the component added by Baddeley in 2000.

options.text: Phonological loop
Visuospatial sketchpad
Central executive
Episodic buffer
Sensory register

questions.explanation: Baddeley and Hitch's (1974) original working memory model included three components: the phonological loop (verbal/acoustic information), the visuospatial sketchpad (visual-spatial information), and the central executive (attentional control). Baddeley added the episodic buffer in 2000, which integrates information across subsystems and links working memory to long-term memory, with a limited capacity of approximately 4 chunks. The sensory register is part of the Atkinson-Shiffrin model, not Baddeley's working memory model.

questions.stem: Select all types of memory that are classified as IMPLICIT (nondeclarative) memory.

options.text: Procedural memory (motor skills like riding a bicycle)
Priming (facilitated processing from prior exposure)
Episodic memory (personal autobiographical events)
Classical conditioning (conditioned emotional responses)
Semantic memory (general world knowledge and facts)

questions.explanation: Implicit (nondeclarative) memory operates without conscious awareness and includes: procedural memory (motor skills, habits -- depends on basal ganglia and cerebellum), priming (facilitated processing from prior exposure -- depends on neocortex), and classical conditioning (conditioned responses -- depends on cerebellum for motor conditioning and amygdala for emotional conditioning). Episodic memory (personal events in time/place) and semantic memory (general knowledge/facts) are both forms of explicit (declarative) memory that require conscious recollection and depend on hippocampal and medial temporal lobe structures.

questions.stem: Select all statements that accurately describe Tulving's distinction between episodic and semantic memory.

options.text: Episodic memory stores personally experienced events with contextual details of time and place
Semantic memory stores general knowledge, facts, and concepts independent of personal context
Patients with hippocampal damage may lose episodic memory while retaining some ability to acquire semantic knowledge
Episodic and semantic memory rely on identical neural substrates with no functional distinction
Semantic memory requires conscious 'mental time travel' to retrieve stored information

questions.explanation: Tulving (1972) distinguished episodic memory (personal events with contextual details, involving 'mental time travel') from semantic memory (general knowledge independent of personal context). Both are forms of declarative memory, but they have partially distinct neural substrates. Patients with hippocampal damage may lose the ability to form new episodic memories while retaining some ability to acquire semantic knowledge, demonstrating a functional dissociation. Mental time travel is characteristic of episodic, not semantic, memory retrieval.

questions.stem: Select all phenomena that demonstrate the operation of the phonological loop component of working memory.

options.text: The phonological similarity effect: similar-sounding items (B, D, G, T) are harder to recall than dissimilar items
The word-length effect: lists of long words are harder to recall than short words
Mental rotation of three-dimensional objects
Subvocal rehearsal of a phone number to keep it in mind
Navigating a familiar environment from memory

questions.explanation: The phonological loop consists of a phonological store and an articulatory rehearsal process. The phonological similarity effect (confusable representations in the phonological store) and the word-length effect (longer words take more time to rehearse) both demonstrate its operation. Subvocal rehearsal of a phone number directly engages the articulatory rehearsal component. Mental rotation and spatial navigation rely on the visuospatial sketchpad, not the phonological loop. This distinction is key to understanding selective interference in working memory.

questions.stem: Select all accurate descriptions of the Atkinson-Shiffrin (1968) multi-store model of memory.

options.text: It proposes three distinct stores: sensory memory, short-term memory, and long-term memory
Information flows sequentially from sensory memory to STM, and with rehearsal to LTM
It was later refined by Baddeley's working memory model, which replaced the unitary STM store
It proposes that information can only flow in one direction and never feeds back from LTM to STM
It accounts for the distinction between explicit and implicit memory systems

questions.explanation: The Atkinson-Shiffrin model proposes three sequential stores: sensory memory (brief, high capacity), short-term memory (limited capacity, ~30 seconds), and long-term memory (unlimited capacity, potentially permanent). Information flows from sensory to STM and, with rehearsal, to LTM. Baddeley's working memory model replaced the unitary STM concept with a multi-component system. The original model did allow for some feedback from LTM, and it did not account for the explicit/implicit distinction, which was a limitation that later multiple memory systems theories addressed.

questions.stem: Match each type of memory with the brain structure(s) most critical for its formation or storage.
questions.explanation: Episodic memory (personal events) critically depends on the hippocampus and medial temporal lobe for consolidation. Procedural memory (motor skills) depends on the basal ganglia, cerebellum, and motor cortex. Fear conditioning depends on the amygdala, which processes the emotional significance of stimuli and enables conditioned fear responses. Eyeblink conditioning (a form of classical conditioning of motor responses) depends on the cerebellum. These distinct neural substrates underlie the dissociations observed in amnesic patients.

questions.stem: Match each sensory memory type with its correct characteristics.

columns.text: Duration ~3-4 seconds; allows 'replaying' of recent speech
Duration ~250-500 ms; demonstrated by Sperling's partial-report paradigm
Duration ~15-30 seconds without rehearsal; capacity of 7 plus or minus 2
Potentially unlimited capacity and permanent duration

questions.explanation: Iconic memory (visual sensory memory) lasts approximately 250-500 milliseconds and was demonstrated by Sperling's partial-report paradigm. Echoic memory (auditory sensory memory) lasts approximately 3-4 seconds, which explains why you can 'replay' something someone just said even if you weren't initially attending. Short-term memory has a capacity of approximately 7 plus or minus 2 items (Miller, 1956) and lasts 15-30 seconds without rehearsal. Long-term memory has potentially unlimited capacity and permanent duration.

questions.stem: For each memory system, select ALL properties that accurately describe it.

columns.text: Involves active maintenance and manipulation of information
Very brief duration with high capacity

questions.explanation: Explicit (declarative) memory requires conscious awareness for retrieval -- you consciously recollect events or facts. Implicit (nondeclarative) memory operates without conscious awareness -- skills, priming, and conditioning influence behavior without deliberate recall. Working memory requires conscious awareness (you are aware of the information you are actively holding) AND involves active maintenance and manipulation of information (not just passive storage). Sensory memory has very brief duration (250 ms for iconic, 3-4 seconds for echoic) with high capacity.

questions.stem: For each clinical scenario, select ALL memory systems that would be expected to remain INTACT in a patient with bilateral hippocampal damage.

rows.text: Learning a new motor skill (e.g., mirror drawing)
Showing priming effects on word-stem completion
Acquiring a conditioned fear response to a tone paired with shock

columns.text: Depends on basal ganglia or cerebellum

questions.explanation: Motor skill learning (procedural memory) is intact after hippocampal damage because it depends on the basal ganglia and cerebellum. Priming is intact because it depends on neocortical perceptual and association areas. Fear conditioning is intact because the conditioned emotional response depends on the amygdala (though the patient will not consciously remember the conditioning experience). Only remembering a conversation from yesterday (episodic memory) is impaired, because it requires hippocampal consolidation of new declarative memories. This pattern of spared implicit memory with impaired explicit memory is the hallmark of hippocampal amnesia.

questions.stem: The Atkinson-Shiffrin model proposes three memory stores. {{blank1}} holds a brief, high-capacity sensory record lasting fractions of a second for vision. {{blank2}} has a capacity of approximately 7 plus or minus 2 items and a duration of 15-30 seconds without rehearsal. {{blank3}} has potentially unlimited capacity and duration. Baddeley replaced the unitary short-term store with a multi-component {{blank4}} that actively maintains and manipulates information.

Short-term memory
The phonological loop
The episodic buffer
Sensory memory
Short-term memory

questions.explanation: The Atkinson-Shiffrin model includes: iconic/sensory memory (brief, high-capacity, fractions of a second for vision), short-term memory (capacity of 7 plus or minus 2 items, duration of 15-30 seconds without rehearsal), and long-term memory (unlimited capacity, potentially permanent duration). Baddeley and Hitch (1974) replaced the unitary short-term store with the working memory model, which includes the phonological loop, visuospatial sketchpad, central executive, and episodic buffer -- an active system that maintains AND manipulates information.

The dissociation between explicit and implicit memory is demonstrated by amnesic patients who show impaired {{blank3}} but intact {{blank4}} across practice sessions.

episodic memory

questions.explanation: Tulving (1972) distinguished episodic memory (personal events in time/place, involving 'mental time travel') from semantic memory (general knowledge independent of personal context). Both are declarative (explicit). The explicit/implicit dissociation is demonstrated by amnesic patients like H.M., who show impaired conscious recollection of learning episodes (explicit deficit) but intact procedural skill improvement across practice sessions (implicit preservation). H.M. could learn mirror drawing despite having no memory of ever having practiced.

questions.stem: A neuropsychologist evaluates a 52-year-old patient who suffered bilateral medial temporal lobe damage from herpes simplex encephalitis. The patient cannot recall what he ate for breakfast or remember meeting the examiner, but can ride his bicycle, tie his shoes, and show normal priming on perceptual tasks. Identify the contributing factors, central concept, and clinical implications.

options.text: Bilateral medial temporal lobe damage destroyed the hippocampal memory consolidation system
Implicit memory systems (basal ganglia, cerebellum, neocortex) remain intact
Global brain atrophy has destroyed all memory systems equally
Damage is limited to the prefrontal cortex affecting executive function
Dissociation between impaired explicit memory and preserved implicit memory
Working memory deficit from central executive dysfunction
Encoding failure from attentional deficits
Procedural learning can be leveraged for rehabilitation despite declarative memory loss
The patient demonstrates that explicit and implicit memory rely on different neural systems
All learning capacity is permanently lost with no rehabilitation potential
The patient's priming and motor skills are merely residual pre-injury memories

questions.explanation: This patient demonstrates the classic explicit/implicit memory dissociation seen in medial temporal lobe amnesia. Bilateral hippocampal damage eliminates the ability to form new declarative (explicit) memories -- he cannot remember breakfast or meeting the examiner (anterograde amnesia). However, implicit memory systems remain intact because they depend on different neural structures: procedural memory (basal ganglia/cerebellum) enables bicycle riding and shoe tying, and perceptual priming (neocortex) is preserved. Clinically, this means procedural learning can be leveraged for rehabilitation, and the preserved implicit systems demonstrate the multiple-memory-systems architecture of the brain.

questions.stem: A school psychologist evaluates a 10-year-old child with ADHD who struggles to follow multi-step instructions, loses track of math problems mid-calculation, and has difficulty organizing essays despite adequate intelligence. Identify the contributing factors, central deficit, and expected assessment findings.

options.text: The central executive of working memory has limited capacity for attentional control
Prefrontal cortex dysfunction impairs the ability to hold and manipulate information
The child has hippocampal damage causing anterograde amnesia
Sensory memory capacity is reduced below normal limits
Working memory deficit primarily affecting the central executive
Implicit memory impairment from basal ganglia dysfunction
Semantic memory loss from temporal lobe damage
Reduced digit span and poor performance on tasks requiring simultaneous storage and processing
Difficulty with dual-task paradigms requiring coordination of phonological and visuospatial information
Intact long-term memory retrieval but impaired ability to hold information while working with it
Complete inability to form any new memories

questions.explanation: This child's difficulties with multi-step instructions, mid-calculation tracking, and essay organization reflect a working memory deficit, primarily affecting the central executive component. The central executive is the most clinically relevant working memory component and is closely associated with prefrontal cortex function. ADHD is strongly associated with central executive deficits. Assessment would show reduced digit span, poor performance on complex span tasks (requiring simultaneous storage and processing), and difficulty with dual-task paradigms. This is not amnesia (hippocampal damage) or implicit memory impairment -- the child can learn new skills but struggles to hold and manipulate information in real time.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are accurate regarding the distinction between explicit and implicit memory.
questions.passage: Memory research has revealed important dissociations between memory systems. [Explicit memory requires conscious awareness for retrieval and includes episodic and semantic memory]. [Implicit memory operates without conscious awareness and includes procedural memory, priming, and classical conditioning]. [Amnesic patients with hippocampal damage show impaired explicit memory but intact procedural learning and priming]. [Patient H.M. could learn mirror drawing despite having no conscious memory of ever having practiced the task]. [Implicit memory depends primarily on the hippocampus while explicit memory depends on the basal ganglia]. [Priming relies on neocortical perceptual and association areas rather than the hippocampal system].

highlightableSegments.text: Explicit memory requires conscious awareness for retrieval and includes episodic and semantic memory
Implicit memory operates without conscious awareness and includes procedural memory, priming, and classical conditioning
Amnesic patients with hippocampal damage show impaired explicit memory but intact procedural learning and priming
Patient H.M. could learn mirror drawing despite having no conscious memory of ever having practiced the task
Implicit memory depends primarily on the hippocampus while explicit memory depends on the basal ganglia
Priming relies on neocortical perceptual and association areas rather than the hippocampal system

questions.explanation: Explicit memory (conscious recollection: episodic and semantic) depends on the hippocampus and medial temporal lobe. Implicit memory (unconscious: procedural, priming, conditioning) depends on basal ganglia, cerebellum, and neocortex -- NOT the hippocampus. Statement h5 reverses this relationship. Amnesic patients like H.M. demonstrate the dissociation: impaired explicit memory with intact implicit learning. H.M.'s mirror drawing improvement without conscious memory of practice is a landmark finding. Priming relies on neocortical association areas, independent of hippocampal function.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are accurate regarding Baddeley's working memory model and its components.
questions.passage: Baddeley's working memory model replaced the unitary short-term store with a multi-component system. [The phonological loop maintains verbal and acoustic information through subvocal rehearsal and holds approximately 2 seconds of speech]. [The visuospatial sketchpad maintains and manipulates visual images and spatial information]. [The central executive is the attentional control system that coordinates subsystems, shifts focus, and inhibits responses]. [The episodic buffer was part of the original 1974 model and has always been a core component]. [Two tasks using the same working memory subsystem interfere more than two tasks using different subsystems (selective interference)]. [The central executive is the component most closely associated with prefrontal cortex function and ADHD].

highlightableSegments.text: The phonological loop maintains verbal and acoustic information through subvocal rehearsal and holds approximately 2 seconds of speech
The visuospatial sketchpad maintains and manipulates visual images and spatial information
The central executive is the attentional control system that coordinates subsystems, shifts focus, and inhibits responses
The episodic buffer was part of the original 1974 model and has always been a core component
Two tasks using the same working memory subsystem interfere more than two tasks using different subsystems (selective interference)
The central executive is the component most closely associated with prefrontal cortex function and ADHD

questions.explanation: The phonological loop holds about 2 seconds of speech-based information through subvocal rehearsal. The visuospatial sketchpad maintains visual-spatial information. The central executive coordinates subsystems and is linked to prefrontal cortex function and ADHD. Selective interference (same-subsystem tasks interfere more) is a key prediction. The episodic buffer was NOT part of the original 1974 model -- it was added by Baddeley in 2000 to account for the integration of information across subsystems and the linking of working memory to long-term memory.

questions.stem: Arrange the stages of memory processing in the Atkinson-Shiffrin model in the correct sequential order, from initial stimulus input to permanent storage.

items.text: Environmental stimulus is detected by sensory receptors
Information enters sensory memory (iconic/echoic) with high capacity but very brief duration
Attended information is transferred to short-term memory (capacity: 7 plus or minus 2 items)
Information is maintained in STM through rehearsal (maintenance or elaborative)
Elaborative processing and rehearsal consolidate information into long-term memory
Information is stored in long-term memory with potentially unlimited capacity and permanent duration

questions.explanation: The Atkinson-Shiffrin model describes a sequential flow: Environmental stimuli are first detected by sensory receptors, then enter sensory memory (high capacity, very brief -- iconic memory lasts ~250-500 ms, echoic ~3-4 seconds). Attended information transfers to short-term memory (limited to ~7 items, lasting ~15-30 seconds). Information in STM can be maintained through rehearsal. Elaborative processing and sufficient rehearsal consolidate information into long-term memory, which has potentially unlimited capacity and permanent duration. Information not attended to or rehearsed is lost through decay or displacement.

questions.stem: Arrange the following long-term memory types from MOST dependent on the hippocampus to LEAST dependent on the hippocampus for formation.

items.text: Episodic memory -- personally experienced events in specific time and place
Semantic memory -- general world knowledge and facts
Priming -- facilitated processing from prior stimulus exposure
Classical conditioning -- conditioned emotional responses (amygdala-dependent)
Procedural memory -- motor skills and habits (basal ganglia-dependent)
Simple reflexes -- basic sensorimotor patterns (spinal cord level)

questions.explanation: Episodic memory is most hippocampus-dependent -- bilateral hippocampal damage produces severe anterograde amnesia for new episodes. Semantic memory is partially hippocampus-dependent (especially for new acquisition, though well-established semantic knowledge can become hippocampus-independent). Priming depends on neocortical areas and is largely hippocampus-independent. Classical conditioning of emotional responses depends on the amygdala. Procedural memory depends on basal ganglia and cerebellum. Simple reflexes operate at the spinal cord level with no hippocampal involvement. This gradient explains why amnesic patients show selective impairment of episodic memory with relative preservation of other systems.

questions.stem: A researcher tests recall of a 15-word list and plots performance by serial position (position 1 = first word presented, position 15 = last word presented). The classic serial position curve shows recall percentage at each position.
questions.question: The difference between immediate recall and recall after a 30-second distractor task is most pronounced at which list positions, and what does this demonstrate?

options.text: The recency effect (final positions) is eliminated by the distractor task, demonstrating that it depends on short-term memory, while the primacy effect (early positions) is preserved because it reflects long-term memory consolidation
The primacy effect is eliminated by the distractor task while the recency effect is preserved
Both primacy and recency effects are equally eliminated by the distractor task
The distractor task has no effect on recall at any serial position

questions.explanation: The serial position curve demonstrates two distinct memory effects: the primacy effect (superior recall for early items, due to greater rehearsal and transfer to long-term memory) and the recency effect (superior recall for the most recent items, due to their continued presence in short-term memory). A 30-second distractor task eliminates the recency effect (items 12-15 drop from high recall to low recall) because it displaces the most recent items from short-term memory. The primacy effect is preserved because those items have already been consolidated into long-term memory. This double dissociation provides strong evidence for the two-store model.

questions.stem: A clinical neuropsychologist assesses a patient with suspected early Alzheimer's disease using various memory tasks over four assessment sessions (6 months apart). The data shows performance scores (percent correct) on explicit episodic memory and implicit procedural memory tasks.
questions.question: What pattern in the data is most consistent with the expected cognitive profile of early Alzheimer's disease?

options.text: Both memory systems decline at the same rate, reflecting global neurodegeneration
Episodic memory shows steep progressive decline while procedural memory remains relatively preserved, reflecting the early vulnerability of hippocampal and medial temporal lobe structures
Procedural memory declines more rapidly than episodic memory
Both memory systems remain stable, suggesting no true cognitive decline

questions.explanation: The data shows a steep decline in episodic memory (62% to 18%, a 71% decline) with relative preservation of procedural memory (58% to 50%, only a 14% decline). This pattern is consistent with early Alzheimer's disease, which initially targets the hippocampus and medial temporal lobe structures (critical for episodic memory consolidation). Procedural memory, which depends on the basal ganglia and cerebellum, is relatively spared in early stages because these structures are affected later in the disease process. This dissociation mirrors the explicit/implicit memory distinction and has important diagnostic and rehabilitation implications.

questions.stem: Categorize each example as representing episodic memory, semantic memory, or procedural memory.

items.text: Remembering your wedding day and the emotions you felt
Knowing that Paris is the capital of France
Being able to ride a bicycle without thinking about how
Recalling where you parked your car this morning
Understanding that water boils at 100 degrees Celsius
Typing on a keyboard with skilled finger movements

questions.explanation: Episodic memory stores personally experienced events with contextual details (wedding day with emotions; parking location this morning). Semantic memory stores general world knowledge independent of personal context (Paris as France's capital; water's boiling point). Procedural memory stores motor skills and habits that are expressed through performance rather than conscious recollection (riding a bicycle; typing). Episodic and semantic are both declarative (explicit), while procedural is nondeclarative (implicit). This taxonomy, developed by Tulving, is fundamental to understanding memory disorders.

questions.stem: Categorize each working memory task as primarily engaging the phonological loop, the visuospatial sketchpad, or the central executive.

items.text: Repeating a phone number silently to yourself until you can dial it
Mentally rotating a three-dimensional object to determine its orientation
Switching between two different tasks and deciding which to prioritize
Remembering the sequence of sounds in a spoken sentence
Navigating a familiar environment from memory without visual cues
Inhibiting an automatic response in favor of a less obvious correct answer

questions.explanation: The phonological loop handles verbal and acoustic information: silently rehearsing a phone number (articulatory rehearsal) and maintaining the sound sequence of a spoken sentence (phonological store). The visuospatial sketchpad handles visual-spatial information: mental rotation of 3D objects (visual cache/inner scribe) and spatial navigation from memory. The central executive handles attentional control functions: task switching and prioritization (shifting attention) and response inhibition (suppressing automatic responses). Understanding which subsystem a task engages is essential for predicting selective interference patterns.
